Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: REAL: INTRINSICS: An Interactive Narrative Technology to Reduce Implicit Negative Stereotyping and Improve the Climate in STEM for Underrepresented Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Women and people from racial/ethnic minority groups are underrepresented in STEM courses, majors and careers in the United States. Social and psychological factors, in particular the prevalence and persistence of negative stereotypes toward underrepresented group members' abilities in STEM, play a key role in explaining and perpetuating this imbalanced level of participation in STEM fields. In particular, the prevalence and persistence of subtle "micro-inequalities" caused by implicit biases and stereotypes, which have taken the place of more overt, intentional forms of discrimination, have contributed to the "chilly climate" faced by underrepresented students in STEM classrooms. Research has revealed that bias persists in STEM educational contexts, even among individuals who value fairness and even among professionals who are themselves members of underrepresented groups. This project will focus on developing, assessing and deploying a digital interactive narrative platform, called INTRINSICS (Interactive Narrative Technology for Reducing Implicit Negative Stereotyping and Improving the Climate in STEM), for use by introductory-level undergraduate STEM instructors and their students that will allow students to express negative subjective classroom experiences, raise awareness about these subjective experiences among instructors and students in the classroom, and empower instructors and students to be proactive in responding to experiences of discrimination.

The project will employ a three-year development and research plan to verify the efficacy and impact of the INTRINSICS platform and its constituent components. In years 1 and 2 (Phase 1: development and guiding research), the technological framework and back-end impact of the platform will be developed and the content, graphics and interface for three modules will be iteratively designed and developed. A set of randomized experiments conducted with undergraduates enrolled in introductory-level physics and biology courses will test the impact of several fundamental variables central to the experience of the platforms narratives, including narrative voice; the generation versus reception of narrative content; the reception of narrative content believed to be fictional versus content believed to reflect people's actual experiences; and the inclusion versus exclusion of interactive elements. The results of the experiments will directly guide the final content and design of the platform's three modules. In year 3 (Phase 2: applied research and deployment), the researchers will employ a longitudinal design to test the long-term impact of the full INTRINSICS platform among students and professors in introductory-level physics and engineering classes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project was to develop effective approaches to reducing the situational and psychological factors that perpetuate inequity in STEM domains. Our approach brought together theories of narrative influence with game design principles. Using stories and games allowed us to create non-threatening ways to raise awareness about bias toward women and underrerpresented groups in STEM, and to improve the climate for these groups.

Our work accomplished three aims: 1) increasing knowledge about the effects of sharing stories of being the target of bias, 2) testing the impact of narratives to raise awareness of bias in STEM, and 3) developing and evaluating game interventions to improve academic self-confidence among women STEM students. As part of each of these research efforts, we also assessed the underlying psychological processes that contributed to the observed effects.

Sharing stories. Previous research suggests that expressive writing about negative experiences can be beneficial for both psychological and physical health. The first phase of our work extended this approach by allowing individuals to share their own stories of being the target of bias; findings indicated that at least in the short term, the benefit of writing their stories depended in part on individuals' traits, such that sharing was more beneficial for individuals with higher self-esteem. This research provided information about the types of bias that undergraduates have experienced. It also contributed to the literature on expressive writing by providing insights into when and how to effectively encourage individuals to share their experiences with bias. 

The second phase of the project drew on individuals' experience of bias to create a series of narrative and game interventions for raising awareness of bias and increasing confidence among women science students. These games included interactive narratives and virtual reality interventions.

Narratives to increase awareness of bias. Our narrative studies indicated that reading stories focusing on a woman student encountering situations that may evoke stereotype threat (the concern that one may be judged based on a stereotype of one's group) helped raise awareness about bias in STEM fields. Some evidence emerged that first-person fictional stories might be especially effective in creating empathy, and the stories were also more effective among women participants. Our work also provided evidence that even very short messages (comics and tweets that describe STEM-relevant events) can be an effective way of raising awareness about these issues.  However, a narrative mystery game intervention designed for high school students showed more mixed effects, indicating that more work may be needed to identify the conditions for games and narratives to successfully raise awareness without creating reactance or backlash. 

Game interventions to increase self-efficacy. Furthermore, our work suggests that games can also be valuable in building academic confidence for STEM students. Two of our game-based interventions led to positive effects among women undergraduates studying STEM. A virtual reality "campus tour" that highlighted successful women in STEM at students' own university increased players' academic self-efficacy, or their confidence that they could handle academic challenges. Similarly, longitudinal data indicated that a fantasy-themed game which required individuals to overcome gender-based obstacles decreased their self-doubt over time.  

In addition to the research contributions and the narrative/game interventions themselves, a further product from the project was a published tutorial for other researchers on creating interactive narratives or story games using the free program Twine. 

Intellectual Merit: These studies provided an integration of narrative theories with game design approaches. Our studies emphasized the importance of empathizing with characters (e.g., individuals experiencing situations of bias or stereotype threat) in raising awareness. In the game contexts, providing positive role models and the opportunity to overcome challenges can increase women's comfort and confidence in STEM fields. Our results contribute to the fields of communication, social psychology, education, and related disciplines.

Broader Impacts: This project provides guidance for effective interventions to both raise awareness of bias in STEM and create positive change. In particular, the ability of games to promote confidence among women STEM students may help with retention of women in science field such as physics and engineering. The use of narratives and games provides a promising avenue for these interventions, but our findings also suggest caveats; such interventions require careful pilot testing to insure that the intended messages are clear and that they do not create reactance effects. In addition to the potential societal impact, the project also provided scientific training for postdoctoral scholars, a graduate student, and undergraduate students.
